name: Slackware
description: Slackware is one of the oldest surviving Linux distributions, known for its simplicity, minimalism, and adherence to UNIX-like principles. It was first released in 1993 by Patrick Volkerding.

sections.title: Early Years
sections.text: Slackware was released in 1993 and quickly gained a following for being a no-frills, stable distribution that closely follows the UNIX philosophy.

sections.title: Growth and Development
sections.text: Though it avoided trends like graphical installers and automatic dependency resolution, Slackware gained a loyal user base that appreciated its simplicity and transparency.

sections.title: Current Status
sections.text: Slackware is still actively developed, although updates are less frequent. It is considered a solid choice for advanced users who prefer manual configuration and a deep understanding of their system.

sections.title: UNIX-Like Simplicity
sections.text: Slackware avoids abstraction and automation. It uses plain text files for configuration, minimal patching, and manual dependency management, providing complete control to the user.
